author: Editor
title: Shaken, not stirred: Crazy cool Caribbean booze cruises
text:
Posted on October 9, 2015 by Editor 
Classic, cool and pure Caribbean, hooch on the high seas is unrivaled holiday bliss. Aboard lively booze cruises, the party hearty step from dry dock to wet bar as soon as the sun sets. With calypso rhythms mixing with the salty sea air and boat bartenders pouring nonstop at open bars, happy hour on a floating nightclub is funky fun par excellence. Check out our suggestions for sunset sipping on comfy catamarans and get your vacation groove on. 
Jamaica 
It’s a three-hour raucous party on the Red Dread as the meandering coastline slips past the bow. Wet and wild, the Reggae Catamaran Cruise departs from Negril and Montego Bay, docking at bubbly watering holes like Jimmy Buffet’s Margaritaville, Pelican Bar and Rick’s Café to watch brazen daredevils dive from the cliffs. The crew on one of the most popular Island Routes tours keeps the crowd swaying to old-school reggae while cruisers learn how to bust a move or two. With snorkeling and swimming an option at various stops along the way, princely pours of Red Stripe and spicy snacks to cut the buzz, the party on the waves departs Montego Bay twice daily on Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Saturday and from Negril and Lucea on Wednesday, Friday and Saturday. 
Barbados For those who prefer to stay onboard; the well-stocked bar is always open. (Photo: Dave Cox) 
On an eye-catching blue, red and green 63-footer, sun salutations on the Sun Blast Jammin’ Catamaran comes with plenty of rum, plenty of dancing, plenty of soca and did we mention plenty of Jammin’ rum punch generously splashed with Mount Gay and fruity juices? With a crew that may have snagged the best jobs on the island, the five-and-a-half-hour daily sail skims the south coast of Barbados, slowing down for a sip in the sea, swim with the turtles or for those who prefer to stay onboard; the well-stocked bar is always open. For snorkelers, there’s loads of exploring below the waves in the wreck of the Berwyn that was reportedly sunk by its own crew in 1919 and the Bajan Queen that went under more recently in 2002. Pick-up is at 9 a.m. at the car park on Cavans Lane, close to the Barbados Hilton in Bridgetown. Tickets are USD$88.00 per person and include the whole shebang, from a chicken and fish buffet that doesn’t forget the essential Bajan macaroni pie to snorkeling equipment and Jammin’ rum punch refills. 
St. Maarten At a leisurely speed of 15 knots (a little more than a mile an hour), sunset sippers groove to the motion of the ocean as they saddle up to the open bar. (Photo: Aqua Mania) 
All hands are on deck as the Tango Caribbean Dinner Cruise sets sail from Aqua Mania Adventures at the Simpson Bay Resort on the Dutch side of the dual-nation island. Twice weekly (Wednesday and Friday) at 5:30 p.m. in sync with the sinking of the sun behind the horizon, the 65-foot catamaran hugs the coastline for a three-and-a-half-hour outing that passes Mullet Bay, the caves and crevices on Cupecoy Beach and the island’s most exclusive resort, La Samanna, sitting pretty along Long Baie Beach. At a leisurely speed of 15 knots (a little more than a mile an hour), sunset sippers groove to the motion of the ocean as they saddle up to the open bar. Large nets up front scare away the occasional raindrop, refills of the Tango’s signature punch stirred with dark rum, cane sugar, orange juice, grenadine and a few secret ingredients are never too far away and funky calypso and reggae keeps everyone on their feet. On the Wednesday sail, the yummy buffet is Dutch and French themed with beef bourguignon and crispy chicken and on Friday; tropical treats rule like those addictive cornmeal flatbreads called Johnny Cakes. Tickets are USD$75 for adults and USD$35 for children ages 5 to 12. 
St Kitts For small groups of up to 20 people, the five-hour voyage departs from the Port Zante Marina in the capital city of Basseterre between 4 p.m. and 5 p.m. as the sun dips in the cool of the afternoon. (Photo: Leeward Islands Charters) 
Moonshine and moonlight are the star attractions on the Sunset and Nevis Beach Bonfire Cruise on catamarans called The Spirit and The Eagle. For small groups of up to 20 people, the five-hour voyage departs from the Port Zante Marina in the capital city of Basseterre between 4 p.m. and 5 p.m. as the sun dips in the cool of the afternoon. After crossing the channel to the tiny isle of Nevis, cruisers enjoy a bonfire on Pinney’s Beach between the Four Seasons Resort and Paradise Beach. A barbecued fish and chicken beach buffet with island sides like coconut coleslaw cap a perfect evening. On the leisurely sail back to St. Kitts, the enthusiastic crew makes sure shots of the local Belmont Estate coconut rum-infused punch and vodka splashed with the sparkling grapefruit soda called Ting are topped up as the stars twinkle in the quiet sky above. “When the moon is full,” smiles Captain Ian Wharton, “it adds magic to the natural beauty.” Tickets are USD$98 and include the open bar, beach barbecue and all the Selfies you can snap. 
Puerto Rico Ideal for night owls who like to drink, the two-hour floating bender departs Friday and Saturday at 10:30 p.m., 12:30 a.m., and 2:30 a.m. and Sunday at 7:30 p.m., 9:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. (Photo: La Rumba) 
Get ready to rumble on La Rumba Party Cruise that heats up the neon-lit two-level sea-worthy funhouse called La Rumba. Moored near Plaza Darsenas at San Juan Bay, the dance bash on the bay is a two-hour shindig around San Juan showing off sights along the way like the 18th-century forts and the coastline of Isla Verde. Disc jockeys playing a nonstop soundtrack of salsa and meringue encourage even the shyest to shake their booty on the disco-lit dance floor. The price for adults is USD$14 (USD$7 for kids – they like to dance too!). The fully-stocked cash bar won’t break the bank at four bucks a pop for a mug of beer. Ideal for night owls who like to drink, the two-hour floating bender departs Friday and Saturday at 10:30 p.m., 12:30 a.m., and 2:30 a.m. and Sunday at 7:30 p.m., 9:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. 
Grenada The ships have a cash bar for those who prefer beer. (Photo: Rhum Runner) 
It’s one rousing party on a pair of catamarans called the Rhum Runners, also known as the 2Hands2 Drinks party boats. Setting sail from St. George’s cruise dock or the Carenage (the pretty waterfront promenade that winds around the Inner Harbour), the three-hour swirl passes the capital city and Grand Anse and includes a stop at Morne Rouge Beach, unlimited rum punch (think: two hands for two drinks) , graze-worthy munchies and a cash bar for those who prefer beer. Steel bands encourage imbibers to enter the limbo competition while the less nimble chill out on the steel hulled, twin-decked 60-foot catamaran Rhum Runner I or its bigger sister called the Rhum Runner II that easily entertains up to 240 party people. 
St Lucia On a clear night, the lucky green flash as the sun leaves the sky is worth waiting for. Island Routes arranges pick up for this popular tour at many hotels including Bay Gardens Beach Resort, Capri St Lucia, Coco Palm, Sandals Grande St Lucia, Sandals Halcyon and Sandals La Toc. (Photo: Island Routes) 
The striking sight of the sun tumbling behind the crest of the Piton Mountains is like a special effects show when viewed aboard the aptly named Sunset Catamaran Cruise. Gliding along the west coast, spin masters rock the boat with tropical tempos as day trippers learn a few Lucian dance moves, munch on apps and toast the picturesque perfection with cocktails, rum punch and champagne that flows nonstop at the open bar. On a clear night, the lucky green flash as the sun leaves the sky is worth waiting for. Island Routes arranges pick up for this popular tour at many hotels including Bay Gardens Beach Resort, Capri St Lucia, Coco Palm, Sandals Grande St Lucia, Sandals Halcyon and Sandals La Toc. Tickets for the two-hour floating party are USD$85 per person with boarding at 5 p.m. on Wednesdays and Fridays.
